Description: Rim and wall sherd of East Greek pottery lid; very micaceoues clay; underside reserved; exterior, cream slip; from centre: undetermined motif; wide black band; frieze of sets of rays and foreparts of water-birds to left, one of each preserved, pendant triangles and rising triangles, blobs and dotted rosette as filling ornament; at rim, hook maeander band between wide black bands. Modern drill hole.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The shape has been discussed; Lamb in CVA took it as a pyxis, and lack of decoration on the underside is not typical of plates (though compare British Museum 1924,1201.1262); it is most probably a lid (not of any regular pyxis). Also published in Kirschner 2001, 82, pl. 7, 4. The clay was analysed as of Group A (= Milesian).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.920)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (36, pl. 18, 13)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 119-20, Nau 84, pl. 18d-e)
